reviewText: Ys Origin from Nihon Falcom is a Japanese take on the ARPG genre, so it's a JARPG I guess. I didn't really know what to expect when I started playing it but I have to say I was pleasantly surprised. The combat is solid and the graphics are charming.  Although you aren't given free reign to upgrade your character like a Western ARPG you level up as you kill monsters which strengthens your stats and you also gain SP by killing monsters which you can use to purchase upgrades for your character to increase passive stats such as Mana Cost for spells. Grinding is also well done in this game, if you kill the monsters as you advance through the game your character will be strong enough to defeat the bosses; however, if you're having trouble with a particular enemy you can grind up to increase your stats if you wish. Speaking of bosses, it was the best part about the game. The boss fights are well designed, challenging, but also fair. It's kind of a find the pattern" type of deal
date: but there's a lot of skill involved in defeating the many bosses in the game. It had a Demon's Souls type of feel for the boss battles but the rest of the game had a Zelda-esque feel to it. The bosses were so fun I thought to myself while playing
recommended: "it would be awesome if this game had a boss rush mode." Little did I know
hoursPlayed: it does! It unlocks after you beat the game.\n\nWhile I enjoyed the game a lot
voteText: it did have a few problems. The game is linear
helpfulPercent: with you having to find a key or item to get to the next area and there isn't an open world as you're just going up a tower. That's not to say the environments aren't varied
votesTotal: it just means there isn't much exploring to do. There's also a bit too much backtracking for my taste
votesFunny: but it wasn't too excessive. The music is pretty low quality and repetative and the control settings aren't adjustable in-game (you have to use a separately loaded launcher) so if you don't have your controller settings set properly you have to exit the entire game to get it right; other than that the controller support in the game is quite good.\n\nThere are three playable characters (one of which is unlockable)
commentsCount: each of which gives you a different point of view on the narrative. The unlockable character is actually a demon as well
column16: so you get the antagonist's point of view on the story which I found quite cool. The story itself is rather tropey
column17: but still was a little more adult than other JRPGs I have played (it has swear words and death) which I enjoyed. The game loads and exits in a snap
column18:
which is also a plus.

Pros:

Gameplay
Storyline (multiple perspectives)
3 Characters that play quite differently
"Grinding" done well for a JRPG
Boss Fights
Unlockables and Bonus Modes (with leaderboard support!)
Excellent Replayability

Cons:

Music/Audio
Backtracking
Linearity

I really enjoyed this Japanese take on the ARPG genre. If you enjoy killer boss fights I'd recommend it for you. There's also a boss rush mode which is amazing for this game and many other unlockables to keep your interest in the game after you've beaten it. The three available characters all play differently and show you a different perspective on the events of the story and I'm really looking forward to coming back and playing this game again once I've finished the other games in my collection. There are a few negative aspects of Ys Origin (I really disliked the audio engineering) but they don't overbearingly detract from the fun I had with this game. A-

NOTE: I did play Ys Oath in Felghana and I have to say I wasn't as impressed with that game as I was with this one.  The boss battles weren't as epic

reviewText:
Score: 8.5 / 10

I haven't 100%'d the game yet, but I feel like I'm ready to review it after 120 hours of gameplay and 3 playthroughs on nightmare on all characters.

I have played three games from the Ys series so far (Ys I & II, Origin and Felghana) and each one of them clearly shows the extreme effort Falcom and XSEED put into every aspect of the game: super smooth gameplay with solid mechanics and very few bugs or inconsistencies, pretty challenging difficulty, excellent performance, very flexible settings that support even 120hz and up monitors and modern resolutions, the portings are very compatible with modern OSes even though these games are from 2006 and earlier, the anime graphics and the artwork are sweet and pleasant (but not necessarily ultra detailed) and the soundtracks are masterpieces.
In poor words, Falcom consistently does a great job in every aspect of the game and puts a great effort into making every detail perfect and solid. Both the engines of Ys I & II and Origin & Felghana have the perfect balance between graphics, performance and gameplay quality.

I won't talk too much about the plot because I usually don't care about that stuff.
Ys Origin is a prequel set 700 years before the events of Ys I & II and tells about the past of Ys, the twin goddesses, the black pearl and Solomon Shrine. Most of humanity fled to Solomon Shrine (which is on a floating island up in the sky), as the surface got taken over by demons. For the very first time we're not playing as Adol. We will be playing as one member of a group of adventurers (you can choose between 3 characters) sent to investigate on the disappearance of the twin goddesses, who seem to be inside the Darm tower.

Pro / Cons:
+ = pro
- = con

- no more bump mechanics" from Ys I & II. In my opinion
date: this combat system was unique and kinda set Ys apart from other action RPG's
recommended: also it made boss fights a bit more challenging. Ys Origin & other newer Ys games ditched that system for more generic hack n slash mechanics + magic which is okay but nothing special.\n- the game takes place entirely inside of the Darm Tower
hoursPlayed: so there is not that much variety environment-wise.\n- while Ys I had very short but extremely fast & challenging boss fights (except for a few bosses with bugged AI's)
voteText: the boss fights on Ys Origin are slow and long
helpfulPercent: and since the bosses heavily rely on RNG
votesHelpful: defeating a boss on Nightmare difficulty is 50% skill 50% luck unless you overlevel to fight that luck factor. Either way
votesTotal: there is too much luck involved in boss fights
votesFunny: and sometimes it can become frustrating even if you can actually beat the boss 100% of the times. This also makes boss rush / time attack extremely tedious and frustrating especially on Nightmare where you will be barely equipped to beat the boss. In Ys I & II
commentsCount: on the other hand
column16: the boss fights were 100% skill based and used nearly no RNG-based attacks
column17: but they were so challenging that you had to practice for a bit to master them even if you memorized them
column18: so the results of the boss fights scaled directly with the player's skill.\n- there is a lot more grinding required
column19: too much for my tastes. Leveling up for bosses takes much longer and filling the monster book is now random instead of having to kill each mob 31 times.\n- the dialogue can be sped up but not skipped. this can be frustrating when playing through the game multiple times.\n- the save system does not allow you anymore to save anywhere - you can teleport to save points
column20: but you will have to save there so that adds some useless backtracking when saving before dangerous situations. On the other hand
column21: the teleport system is handy to quickly teleport to every area of the game
column22: but a system like the wings in Ys II would've been enough.\n- Alt + F4'ing the game has a chance to corrupt your monster book\n+ a playthrough takes about 10 hours if you kill all of the bosses first try and 20-30+ hours if you take a few tries to beat each boss
column23: which is pretty optimal for multiple playthroughs or speedruns.\n+ amazing soundtrack with lots of remasters of the original darm tower musics in Ys I\n+ lots of references to Ys I & II: remastered bosses
column26: some key items in common and the plot is nicely linked and properly explains all of the backstory behind Ys I.\n+ very high replay value: each character sees the story from an entirely different perspective
column27: will encounter slightly different bosses and each character's boss fight is balanced differently. There's also an arena mode where you will be able to fight monsters from different areas of the game to gain SP you can use to unlock alternative versions of the characters and other bonus content
column28: including a secret boss. Completing all of the achievements will take up to 6 playthroughs or more. There's also the usual monster book you have to fill by grinding all of the monsters in the game (some are missable)
column29: an upgrade system for your characters where you can spend SP earned from mobs
column30:
and various Roo's hidden around the game that will give you missable upgrades if you feed them Roda Fruits (also hidden & missable).
+ the achievements where you have to beat two "unbeatable" boss that you normally have to lose to are pretty interesting challenges even though they're heavily rng based
+ retrying bosses doesn't make you go through the dialogue all over again
+ perfect support for the 360 joypad and ps3 joypad + ds3 tool

that way there is always a guaranteed minimum framerate even in the worst scenario.
+ the bosses partially retain the "bullet hell on foot" feel that Ys I & II had.

It's not a masterpiece like Ys I & II

reviewText:
J-Just.... THE EMERSION! A game that, to me, gave a really good bonding experience with the playable characters. Good difficulty and balance, yet still the possibility to easily gain some more fighting strength for tough fights.

Not many games do, but this game gave me that empty feeling of sadness when it was over. I was forced to consider what just occured, and the meaning of it. And let me tell you, my conclusion wasn't a happy one. Knowing that your character was done and that you would never again experience the same thing is not very pleasant in this case. This is something I rarely see in the modern gaming genres. I want to mention a couple of things to those who have doubts about this game.

It's a japanese game, so it does have some anime-esk cut-scenes and images. Yet, these occur very rarely, so do not be concerned if you think this would bother you (Though, seriously, why would it?).

It's an old game, don't look for good graphics and such. Though, that's not what you primarily should be looking for in a game.

The gameplay feels smooth and fast-paced, something that I thoroughly enjoyed. Characters that are extremely unique and different from one another. Discovering the plot feels utterly fantastic. Any time something plot-related occured in between my beat up sequences, I couldn't help but let my excitement lead me through the dialogues. Remember when I mentioned I felt really empty and sad about my character that I played? How I wasn't going to be able to see her anymore? Well, that happened with not only that one, but some NPCs as well. Definitely an achievement.

Something more about difficulty. The game has 5 difficulty settings, two above and below normal. This makes it very suitable for people of all skill levels or interests. Keep in mind that you cannot change your difficulty throughout the game, yet this is also not necessary as you will always be able to beat the boss without exception because of the possibility to grind a level or two. Not once have I felt like a boss was truly overpowered. Rather, that I, myself, was underpowered. And that is something that's easy to fix.

Now, something I really appreciate about this game is that you have 3 playable characters. One of which is unlocked by finishing the game with one of the other two. This is because the final one is the hardest one to play and to minimize sploilers for the other two. The reason for that is something you will have to find out for yourself. The last one also has the one true story, meaning, the heaviest plot. This gives the game amazing replayability.

That is about the best I can give you. If this has not cleared things up for you regarding gameplay and such, I'd say you oughta simply look up a video and see for yourself. Try to minimize spoilers, however! So, to conclude my review, this game is heavily recommended by myself among others.

An Awesome Action-JRPG with typical JRPG tropes great gameplay and multiple characters encourages multiple playthroughs.

Within an hour of booting this up, I was hooked. This is pure unbridled hack-n-slash fun. With multiple character styles, difficulty levels, and extra challenge modes, it's a game that's easy to pick up, but hard to put down, even after completing the main story.

Ys Origin is that one game I have been waiting for to make me feel like a child again. I orginally got this game because I have played some other Nihon Falcom games.

This game completely blew me away. This series is now on my top 10 list just from playing this one game. The fighting is fun and quirky and makes me wish more games took this kind of play style. On top of that the story was perfect. The writers took great detail in making sure that you fell in love with the character. Granted I have only played one character and there are two more I can play, but I completely fell for Yunica our heroine.

This to me is one of the best games I have played and will always have a place in my heart.

Overall: 9.5/10

Ys Origins is a mix between Diablo and Zelda, and it is very fun to play. Unfortunately the great gameplay, soundtrack and visuals are dragged down by downright cringeworthy dialogue and a by the numbers story with a very flat ending. The graphics are also a bit dated even for 2006 when this originally came out. However the game still has a charm of its own. The character sprites are well made and environments have clear and different themes and feels. The fast pace of the monster slaying is maybe a bit too often grinded into a halt when you have to sit through lengthy and uninteresting line exchanges between the monotone and cliche characters.

One interesting thing of note is the other main character of the game, Hugo. He should probably get an award for the most edgy video game protagonist ever. Most of the cringe material of the game comes from his teenage rebel attitude. The story might have been much less cringy had I picked Yunica for playable character, but I also think the edginess is kinda charming and memorable.

In conclusion the rock solid gameplay and soundtrack totally redeem this game from any negatives I might have towards it. It was a blast to play and a definite recommendation.

Ys origin is a great game,its an action-jrpg that has all the elements that makes Ys series great, the huge difficult bosses, the fast paced action, the amazing music.
This one follows the style of the modern 3D Ys games like oath in felghana and ark of napishtim but the story is a prequel of the whole Ys series, before Ys I & II chronicles. It does a great job explaining how the story started with interesting characters and a plot that suits the game. Dont expect an amazing plot but its decent.
As for the content, the game offers three playable characters (one fo them is unlocked after you complete the game with one of the first two) with different story for each one, also there is boss rush,time attack and an arena mode, so there is lots of things to do. Just for completion with one character you will need about 12 hours in normal difficulty.
The game can be really hard so think carefully before starting it in hard mode for a first playthrough.

I highly recommend this game for hack and slash action-jrpg fans.

This game is addicting and offers tons of challenge. The feeling when you finally figure out how to beat a boss is impossible to duplicate with any other game. If you are looking for a game that has good music, good gameplay, and not much of a story, this is for you.

Ys Origin is a fantastic and surprising game. At the start it appears to be a fairly standard JRPG-esq story with the memorable and challenging hack and slash gameplay Ys is known for, but as you play through the game multiple times with each of the characters, what was first a simple, borderline cliche, if well executed tale becomes far more memorable, complex, and touching. No other game I've seen tells a story like it, and its a damn good story to boot. With memorable characters and story, fantastic gameplay, and a mindblowing soundtrack, there is little reason not to get Ys Origin as soon as you can.

I have yet to find anything really wrong with this game.  It plays very much like an old-school RPG but with action elements instead of turn-based combat.  You're slashing, smashing, and magicking your way through a 20-something story tower full of demons.  I don't want to go much into the story because that's half of what makes this game so brilliant.  I haven't played a game with such a great story in a very long time.  Finish this game through to the end as well, because there's a bunch of unlockables (time-attack and an arena battle mode, to name a couple... naming more would be spoilers).  The replay value is pretty good but if you're going for a 100% completion it could take a long while.

Gameplay-wise, it has a few quirks to get used to, and it'll take some time, but once you've got it down it's pretty easy.  The boss battles are INSANE, and there are a LOT.  If you're a fan of great boss fights, you'll love this game.  Each difficulty brings a new attack pattern, etc. to the bosses in addition to basically oneshotting you if you're not properly leveled/geared.

The only qualm I can see that some people might have is that, like I mentioned earlier, if you aren't properly leveled you're going to have a rough time in certain areas of the game (bosses in particular).  The good news is that you'll catch on pretty quick.  The bad news is that you might have to sit there grinding enemies for a while - which isn't too bad, but you have to make sure you save often just in case.

TLDR: Fantastic story, quirky controls, fantastic boss fights, lots of unlockables and decent replay value.

Pick this game up and if you want more of the story, pick up Ys I & II as well as Oath in Felghana.  All four games are worth it, trust me.

This is a pretty amazing game. It may not look like much at first but believe me, once you start playing you'll enjoy every bit of it.

The gameplay is solid and the boss fights keep you on your toes - every boss has some kind of weakness which you need to discover and then exploit in order to beat them (something you don't see very often).

As for the story - it's AWESOME! Some may find it a little cliche but for me it offered a very enjoyable experience. In addition, you get to experience it through the eyes of three different characters - Yunika, Hugo and a mystery character (You unlock him after beating the game as either Yunika or Hugo)

I personally had never played a game of this genre before (Japanese RPG) so I'm not really sure to which type of player to recomment it to... All I can say is that I've had a blast with it and definitely recommend it. :)

reviewText: I picked this up in the japanese humble bundle and was pleasantly surprised. I came for Asterbreed but stayed for Ys Origin. I'm not a huge fan of jrpgs and I generally consider them a bit boring (yes even the mythical FF7), but Ys origin has a more realtime, action rpg take on things and it works. In it's simplicity this game puts many AAA titles in shame by it's design, writing and gameplay. Perhaps in 100+ people development teams the heart of fun is often lost. Or maybe the developers of Ys know what they are doing. Either way, give this one a shot.

Now, let me just say that Falcom and Xseed games did a respectable job with this installment of the Ys series but it is not a game without its flaws. Lets start with the things I really liked. The gameplay was wonderful, honestly I would change a thing about it. Yunica moves where you want, attacks where you want, slaughters thousands of enemies in an effort to grind levels, the way you want... and umm hmm I'll talk about that pretty soon. The visual style was really good to look at with a SNES era feel to it. Although, same of the 3D environments looked a little choppy and jagged it was enough to take away from the game. I liked the good use of colour throughout the games many different environments. What I found really neat that despite the fact you spend the entire game inside a tower the developers still put floors dedicated to elements such as desert, water and lava. My favourite part of the game was hands down the combat which was a pleasure to utilize. The boss fights were always overwhelming and in general were very unique. They provided a great deal of challenge to the player and some would not be defeated easily. Just my basic two cents on what I feel was done right.

On the other hand there are some areas for improvement that I feel should be touched on. I'm not providing any plot spoilers but I do think the story was all anything to special. If you look at the whole picture then maybe the story is more meaningful, but the events leading up to the end just felt a little bit empty to me. I'm not saying it's bad but it just wasn't what I was expecting. Another thing that I found rather bland was the characters. They weren't very likeable and for that matter many of them just felt forced into the game. A lot of them were unlikeable and literaly added nothing to the game or the story. The villians of the game didn't really have a reason as to why they wanted ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up. A character later in the game dies and the plot sets it up to be very emotional but I think that character had maybe like a dozen lines of dialogue before hand. Anyway, enough about the story elements lets get to the elephant in the room. That's right a JRPG's best friend, grinding. Oh, Jesus Christ, the grinding. Let me just say that I played though this game on normal and I probably spent a very sizable amount of my time proforming mass genoside on these creatures. Why is it that even though I kill all of the enimies in the area, when I get to the boss he rips my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in half? Seriously, like I slaughtered every enemy on the way to the fight and the boss don't give a ♥♥♥♥. So, what do you do? You go back and grind until you level up again. Alright, round 2 you piece of ♥♥♥♥ boss mother ♥♥♥♥er. Nope. You lost again. Game over. Welp, I guess I grind some more levels. This time the boss is ♥♥♥♥ed, right? Nope. ♥♥♥♥ you. And when you finally beat the ♥♥♥♥er you cele-♥♥♥♥ing-brate because you know that all that grinding is past you. You are like overleveled now so, time to go to the next area. The first new enemy you find in the next area does more god damn damage then the ♥♥♥♥ing boss you just beat. At this point you are just like whyyyyy? Why Falcom why? And they are all like ♥♥♥♥ you thats why! So then after crying for half an hour you go back to the last area and grind so you can fight the enemies in the next are and not die. see a pattern here. I've seen more grinding in this game than a the club for ♥♥♥♥ sakes. The worst instance was charging the Evil Ring. After trying to figure out how that criptic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t worked, I finally figured out I had to kill those sand goat things an area back. So I start attacking the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and only do 1 ♥♥♥♥ing damage to the little ♥♥♥♥. I start attacking the other monsters in the room and do like 55 to them. So what the ♥♥♥♥ am I doing wrong? Since the trend has been grind grind grind so far I was like fine I'll just level up, it won't be so bad. I ♥♥♥♥ you not, after leveling up 3 ♥♥♥♥ing times, I still did 1 god damn, mother ♥♥♥♥ing, ♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥ing damage. After stabbing a pencil into my crotch and not playing the game for 4 months I learned that one of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥s at the bottom floor upgrades your weapon for you. Now Falcom/Xseed if you can can excuse my language for a second. Ahem... HOW THE ♥♥♥♥ AM I SUPPOSE TO KNOW THAT!?!?! How the ♥♥♥♥ is anyone supposed to know that 4 eyes down there has mastered such witchcraft! reviewText:
Overall: A linear adventure from the Ys history books that, despite taking place in one buliding, has a good deal of visual variety and some strong chracter beats in its otherwise-short running time.

Pros:Two characters (with an unlockable third) each with different perspectives on the cutscenes and different playing styles.  Each level looks and feels markedly different from the others, no mean feat in a tower-based game.  Some truly fantastic music every step of the way.  The play control is smooth and seamless whether running, jumping, or fighting.  The short length makes multiple playthroughs easier (and recommended, as the unlockable chracter gives great insights onto the bigger story).

Cons: It takes place inside a tower so, for as much variety as they go for, it's alawys indoors and in one geographical location.  The story is accordingly simple as it is a straight shot up to the final battle.

Rating: **** / *****

OK, this was my first time playing an Ys title, so let me say this:\n\nMix Zelda and Diablo with some steroids and you get ThYs! DEFINETELY worth them 16€! DEFINETELY supporting the series from now on!

reviewText:
A fun Action-RPG with multiple character with different play styles, an enjoyable storyline and extra game modes. With the bosses and difficulties giving you a constant challenge, it's definitely not a game you can just plow through. Good loot is scattered across the tower that require you to use your wits and abilities to obtain.

Each character tells a pretty similar story from their point of view. So the replay value is pretty nice. You start off with 2/4 characters and unlock the others (with their EX versions) after some rewarding hard work.

Overall, this game is worth the money. It's fun to see a game that isn't 100% easy all the time nowadays.
The art is nice, the characters are interesting and the gameplay is great. Oh, and that OST... <3

Ys Origins is a old school JRPG time of game. part of the Ys franchise it is actually a prequel to the other games. Its action packed, the boss fights are hard and has a reasonable good soundtrack being very good at times. I'll add that the story, while being a bit thin, does start to grow on you speacially after you unlock the third playable character and start to play with him.

There is also plenty to do and a good replayability value given all the unlocks the game have like arena modes and as I said 3 playable character in the campaign.

I recomend it for fans of this type of games as well as someone who enjoys a chalenge.

Responsive gameplay, great music and amazing boss battles. A fun game overall but be aware achievementhunters, this game has the finish the game a lot of times" kind of achievements which might put you off."

reviewText: I think the Ys series is really underrated, or maybe it just hasn't had the advertising it did overseas.  These games go way back and there have been several remakes of the originals, including Ys 1 and 2 that are available on Steam.  I recommend anyone that is a fan of action or RPGs to take a look at these.  If you want a more modern game then go for Oath in Felghana or Origin; Ys 1 and 2 have a much different gameplay but I still thoroughly enjoyed them.\n\nFor the most rewarding experience, play them on Nightmare difficulty.

reviewText:
Ys Origin is an excellent game. I was expecting an average action rpg but it ended up being one of my favorite action rpgs to date. The game can be quite difficult at certain points, especially boss battles, even on the easier difficulties. Also the entire soundtrack is superb.

So far I've finished the game with Yunica and I've started playing the game as the other two characters (the second of those two must be unlocked by beating the game with either Yunica or Hugo). Each character plays differently from the others and the story for each character is also different (although your going to be running through the same areas and fight most of the same bosses as well).

After beating the game with a character it unlocks an arena mode for that character, other unlockables are also unlocked after beating the game with all three of the characters.

I'd recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of action games or action rpgs, I'd say its a must buy.

reviewText:
After playing Ys I and II, how I think of this game is much different. It drags along Ys I and II's coattails too much at times, so this hampers the story mode (recycled puzzles from those games, to name a few). Also there are a ton of unskippable cutscenes so it makes the multiple playthroughs required to get everything tiring.
The gameplay is good aside from horrendous imbalance between characters (bosses were not balanced around multiple characters very well, so the worst character in the game will have loads of trouble against a boss that can easily be defeated with the better" characters).
Soundtrack is pretty great.

8/10
Go play Oath in Felghana or Ark of Napishtim for a better Ys experience."

reviewText:
Fun and positively addictive combat system. Grinding in this game is one of the best grinding experiences in ARPG. Boss battles are tricky and sometimes incredibly brutal, with an upward trend of difficulty in attack patterns and damage received from the first boss to the very last, which is always a crucial key in boss battles design.

Storyline is straightforward and fluid with epic twists (the most literal sense of 'epic'). Covers most of the important key points that explain what happens in the main series, while also leaves very much room for personal interpretation and possibly retelling.

Character designs are surprisingly intricate and interesting, considering the fact that Falcom had always been set with simplicity in all Ys titles until Ys Origin came out in 2006.

Not much needs to be said about the music. Falcom JDK Band did a fantastic job as usual. I believe the music in Ys Origin is about as well-praised as that of Oath in Felghana. Beyond the Beginning is personally my favorite track.

The only potential problem with the game is everything stays the very same throughout all three arcs, except for character combat mechanics, storyline, and minor spoiler: a true final boss. This can be boring to some people, but not to me personally.

Overall, this is definitely a very solid and highly polished dungeon-crawler ARPG from Falcom, and a worthy title to mark the big jump of the series to Ys Seven. Absolutely a huge Yes from me.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Maybe my biggest surprise / gut purchase ever. Ys is one of those darling series where everyone seems to want to tell you how good it is yet few people have played. While I won't say it's become one of my favorite series, it's become one I've begun to follow, and it along with Trails in the Sky has put Falcom on my mental map when it comes to video games.\n\nYs, pronounced something like ease" with only the first letter capitalized and no apostrophe
date: is basically an action jrpg without random battles or a heavy story emphasis. There's a moderate amount of text dialogue but it's interesting enough and no voice acting to drag it down. Ys Origin is essentially a far prequel to the events of Ys I and II
recommended: also available on Steam but significantly more dated. You are given two choices of characters. Yunica provides gameplay more similar to that of series protagonist Adol
hoursPlayed: specilizing in close combat fighting. Hugo seems to be a more experimental playstyle for the series
voteText: focusing on long range magic attacks.\n\nI strongly suggest Yunica to be your first playthrough character for the game. Her playstyle is simply exceedingly more engaging than Hugo
helpfulPercent: who simply becomes a button spam unless playing at one of the more difficult settings. Luckily to unlock the third character you only need to beat the game as one of these two
votesHelpful: which is nice if you want to experience the full canon story of the third character without slogging through a Hugo playthrough. Though you may find you don't mind and will want to play his story anyways.\n\nYs Origin is a brief experience
votesTotal: which is good considering that if you want to see everything you have to play the game a few times. It also allows for replays and taking on higher difficulties if you find you truly want to master the battle system. While the common enemies may not offer much lateral thought in how you tackle them
votesFunny: the frequent and varied boss encounters are quite a relative spectacle and there's no re-skinning or re-hashing to be seen here. All of them are tackled in a different way.\n\nThere is a plethora of music selections for each section of the tower. The whole soundtrack is great an I often found myself humming some of the more memorable tracks. There's also good variety
commentsCount:
so finding a few floors with a theme you don't really care for is offset by knowing that a new track is just around the corner.

Definietly consider it if you are looking for a unique jrpg without the bloat that SE or someone like NamcoBandai puts out these days.

8.5/10"

reviewText:
-Wonderful Japanese Action Role-Playing Game.
-The game is beautiful and the controls work wonderfully. Perhaps a controller would be easier to navigate but so far the keyboard hasn't been too frustrating.
-The enemies all seem to be unique and pose different challenges.
-The boss battles are so far very well crafted and takes some skill... again easier with a controller.
-You unlock skills as you progress similar to how you would in say metroid... which I will mention because whenever you open a chest you get the wonderful metroid new upgrade sound effect.(That's what it sounds like to me!)
-Music sounds great and well done.
-Storyline so far is interesting and enjoyed the usage of the Sosarian Runes, which i know from the old Ultima games.. and is similar to Dwarven Runes from Lord of the Rings. All being based off of the Germanic languages. (So far not needed to know during the game, but provided some extra interest.)
-Great save point locations so you don't waste too much time from deaths.

reviewText:
Ys Origin plays like a top-down hack-and-slash but can at times be so frantic it feels like a bullet hell. Think Zelda on steroids. An interesting story, awesome gameplay, and very challenging. Well worth the money and made me purchase the other Ys games - which I am also enjoying.

You are given the choice of playing as a girl with a big axe or a guy with magic. After you beat the game you can go ahead and replay it with the other character or with a new, 3rd character. Playing it with the girl or guy you're first given feels generally the same, although you obviously have an entirely different set of skills. All three characters pretty much trek through the exact same dungeon layout but the 3rd character you unlock fights a set of new bosses and has an entirely different story. Playing on higher difficulties actually changes things besides HP and damage - although the story stays the same.

One downside is that I feel that the leveling was pretty tedius. You will find yourself in positions where you need to grind out 5 levels because it is literally impossible to beat a boss if you don't have the damage output. This only takes maybe 10-15 minutes before each boss but later in the game I remember having to spend an entire hour just beating up 1,000 grunts.

Defintely one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a while.

reviewText: An expansion pack sequel to Oath in Felghana, Ys Origin has much of the same feel of it's predecessor. New enemies and world to explore, but you handle exactly like Adol Christin, wind-powered spinny attack and all. Origin has three campaigns to justify that extra five dollars on the price tag, but they're all the same, with the exception of bosses. With the same puzzles and monsters, I finished Yunica's campaign but only scratched the surface of the other two, dropping them once I felt like I was going through the motions.\n\nWhat bothers me about the Ys series is that I don't think Falcom understand why their game is good. Every single one of their games starts with at least five minutes of cutscenes, with Oath in Felghana clocking in at 15 before you start to slay monsters. Game, I don't need you to tell me to beat up monsters. Legend of Zelda had an old man in a cave saying take this sword and ♥♥♥♥ off" and I still saved the world without knowing why or caring. Damningly
recommended: you get thrown into a supposed-to-lose boss battle
hoursPlayed: and then your character mopes around for another five minutes of cutscene until your male love interest (no homo) cheers you up and encourages you to keep going. All the while I'm thinking about how much fun I'd be having if I was playing the game. This game needs less talky talky

reviewText:
Okay, let's just get the obvious out of the way right now: The intro to this game is LONG. LOOOOONG. Like, possibly the longest intro to an RPG I've ever played.

HOWEVER, once you get past the intro, you're introduced to the meat of the gameplay, and holy hell is it satisfying! The combat in Ys: Origin is fast placed hack n slash that seems mindless at first, but if you just mindlessly spam attacks with no thought, you will die. A lot.

In fact, even if you're careful, you will most likely die a lot, because this game is HARD. The normal enemies are usually no trouble, though there are indeed cases where they can chump you if you're not careful, but the real meat of the difficulty lies in the boss battles.

If you're at all familiar with the Ys series, than you probably know that one of the series' most lauded aspects is the incredibly designed, incredibly difficult boss fights, and Origin is no exception. You will most likely die to a boss at least once before you learn how to deal with them. And each boss as their own styles, attacks, and strategies, so each boss feels fresh and exciting.

Also, did I mention the music? Because HOLY HELL the music is amazing. Quite possibly one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard.

All in all, if you're looking for an RPG with fast paced action, an interesting story, amazing bosses, amazing soundtrack, and a difficulty level that constantly keeps you on your toes, then Ys Origin is for you. In fact, give the whole Ys series a try. Its a great series, and Falcom and XSeed are great companies that deserve your support.

reviewText: This game serves as my introduction to the world of Y's (pronounced EES). I've been wanting to play a game in this series for a while and I'm so happy I picked this one up. A Diablo-style action RPG, this game is hella fun. I'm several hours into my first playthrough and have really enjoyed it so far. Challenging boss fights, decent level design that rewards you for exploring while providing a decent story. It's all a very solid and polished experience that's worth your time. A lot of games like this have mecahnics that suffer or that are a bit loose. To me, this is a crucial part of enjoying a game's platforming sections. It's very frustrating when you feel like you told your character to jump from the platform they're on to the one on the right only to find that you were pressing every so slightly in an upwards/downwards direction which caused you to miss the platform and fall into the pit. Not so here. I felt like I had good control over the character and rarely if ever made such a mistake that felt all too common even in AAA titles that are top ranked in their class.\n\nOverall I really can't find much to fault in this game. To nitpick I'd say the costumes are a bit plain when you're talking to others but this is also refreshing at the same time. It's simple, and practical. I would also say there maybe could have been more variety with the monsters but this doesn't really bother me at all either. It's just a fun game that's knows what it is and has fun being just that. If you like games like this I highly recommend giving it a try.

reviewText: Action-packed, a fine story, lots of great boss battles (AMAZING boss battles!)… this is a hacky-slashy JRPG that has it all. The game might look kind of old, but it’s still pretty and plenty of fun. If you’ve played OiF, then the gameplay will feel quite familiar. There are three (one of them must be unlocked) main characters, each with their own style of fighting. The story takes place before the events of Ys I and II, which fans suggest you play before starting this one. Don’t let that stop you from picking this one up whenever you can though! Show your support! Falcom and XSEED are a match made in heaven. I really hope they continue to bring over games to this side of the pond for a long time to come. Overall, Ys Origin has to be one of the best games I’ve bought on Steam, and I’m really happy to have it in my library.

The back story on Ys was something I never cared about and this game didn't really do a good attempt at making me care now... so yeeeeeah. reviewText:
Ys Origin is one of the best games I've ever played.

It has the perfect balance between story, music and gameplay.  The combat is simple to learn but hard to master if you want to tackle higher difficulties or venture into Arena or Time Attack mode.  You'll probably want to use a controller.  The story in this game is simply one of the most perfectly paced and emotionally driven games I've had the pleasure of playing.  This game completely blows every other Ys game out of the water (Take that, Adol!).  If you're a Ys fan, or any sort of JRPG fan, or even an anime fan, this game was made for you.

With every track of music that is perfectly tuned for each area to match the locale, to the incredibly deep characters that have their own personal motivations and feelings, this game will blow your socks off and keep you guessing about some of the characters until the very end.  This is what game design should be about.  Graphics don't matter, they don't have to cost millions of dollars, they just need a little bit of love.

Praise the Goddesses.

reviewText: The Ys series is a long runnning action RPG series from way back in the 1980s. In 2006 a prequel to the first two games in the series was made called Ys Origin" it  allowed you to play as three different characters with three different playstyles and abilities. You got to move around a strategize how you were going to attack your foes with melee or magic spells in nicely done varied areas such as a water and fire sections. The game has some platforming and slight puzzle sections at times too which is a nice change of pace. Falcom here again did a nice OST to listen too while your killing those bosses or even when jumping from area to area or running down hallways killing everything in sight. The story as already mentioned is a prequel telling more of the story established in earlier Ys games and connecting them. It's nice and each character you play as has their own little portion in the plot I really like games that do that. If you are craving some action based JRPGs check out this game for sure you won't regret it! :)"

reviewText: An incredible action RPG with 3 campains and a hard-rock soundtrack.  Each character has their own story that unfolds at a very pleasing rate, but these characters also go to the same places and almost do the same things.  As far as Ys games go this one is definitely one of the best.  One warning though, it is not the best Ys game to start on if you care about the story.  Gamplay wise this game is less like Ys Seven and more like Ys: The Oath in Felghana (Also on steam).  You have three crystals that you will obtain over time and you can upgrade them to do more stuff and get stronger.  This game also has an upgrade system for your armor, weapons, and resistances.  Music wise the Ys games are second to none, a blaring hard rock soundtrack (Plus remixes from Ys 1 & 2).  On a final note, if you like action RPGs or fantasy games this game here is a must buy.

reviewText:
It's a very linear game and the plot is pretty unoriginal, but executed well enough to make me feel emotionally invested in the later boss battles.  Each level is a 3D puzzle platformer full of hacking and slashing.  Many of the later boss battles become like shoot-em-up/bullet hell games, except that you A: fight melee (if you choose the melee character, which I did), and B: can jump over the bullets.  Each boss requires a nuanced combination of strategies.

The RPG elements are pretty minimal, and the XP system is such that you can't grind ahead of the area's level, but you always catch up the area's level before you reach the boss, even if you try to avoid enemies.  IMO that's a pretty good thing, since it means that there is nothing to distract you from the meat of the gameplay.  (It is vital that you find all of the hidden items, though, at least on hard mode).

Also, while the environments are kinda simple, some of the shader effects look pretty good, the character portrait and sprite art are beautiful, and special effects for character and boss attacks are completely ridiculous (but totally interactive and quite sophisticated; pretty much no scripted execution nonsense).

Oh, and I forgot to mention that the music is fantastic.  I still regularly listen to the soundtrack.

reviewText:
Adding RPG stats to an action game always weakens the game, but despite that flaw Ys Origin has some of the best hack and slash boss battles on Steam outside of Ys Oath in Felghana and the bosses alone make the game worth playing. Each is a brutal brick wall requiring a lot of learning and retries to get all the patterns down, and, yes, unfortunately, a touch of grinding is required sometimes. There are levels you are meant to be at, as the boss time attack mode makes clear, and sometimes you don't get to those levels without going back and bashing mooks for a while. Still, at the right level, you can treat Ys like a real game and not yet another RPG grindfest.

Other problems, it's flatly worse than Ys Oath in Felghana. The mook combat is more interesting but the addition of multiple characters with different styles screws the balancing all up.

The story tells an origin" that doesn't really ever justify itself. The priests of Ys had no grand mystery behind them and other than locking you in a dreary endless tower and throwing a lot of redone Ys 1 and 2 enemies at you
date: this story ends up offering no real insight to the Ys story
recommended: nor does it ever really get interesting enough to justify the freakishly long unskippable cutscenes.  Oath had a bloated tale too but at least it was a rollicking good adventure. Origin isn't even that.\n\nStill
hoursPlayed: if you liked Oath and want another helping of those amazing boss battles
voteText: Origin is worth your time. Even if the balancing is off
helpfulPercent: the variety is here in spades. If you haven't played Oath yet

reviewText:
Many have dismissed Ys Origin as a cheap cash in game, a place holder between other, more successful games. Yet I'm not one of those; sure, it's basically Ys I&II: The Before Years, but that's EXACTLY why I enjoy the game. Ys as a series has been sorely lacking in back story; many key events in the past have been teased by Falcom, yet we've never seen them. Ys Origin, thankfully, does the job of offering us SOME insight to the history of the flying island, several bosses/main villains of Ys I&II and, finally, the reason why the Goddesses of Ys lost their wings.

Even though Oath of Felghana and even Ark of Napishtim are better in certain aspects, Origin IS NOT in any way truly inferior to them. It has the same great engine and game play of the others, and despite, or perhaps maybe in spite of the fact that it's all contained within Darm Tower, Ys Origin earns its place in my heart for giving me precious back story that's been so scarce.

Oh, and Adol is unlockable. JOY!

reviewText:
Ys isn't as bad as the first few hours make it seem.  There's enough about it that's bad enough to give it a thumbs down, but it's definitely done some things pretty well.  This review lists major points concisely with more detailed explanations at the bottom.

Here are the flaws I've seen so far:
-Character and item upgrade systems are pathetically bad.
-Uninspired levels.
-The 'puzzles' involve finding an item and backtracking to use it.
-Framerate issues with some graphical effects.
-Controls need autofire and autocharge.  Other control problems may be specific to me.
-Too many rpg text dialogs that can't be skipped.
-The difficulty curve isn't right.
-The rate of levelling needs adjusting, and the effect of gaining levels is not done well.  It increases damage done and decreases damage taken, altering boss fight difficulty too much.

Game's strong points:
+The bosses are very challenging with fully-avoidable attacks
+The action is fast-paced.
+The graphics are colorful, and I like the graphical style of the characters.

Regarding difficulty,
On Hard difficulty with the magic user, the monsters are a joke, unable to threaten the player.  The bosses are very challenging.  On nightmare difficulty with the melee character, the (skippable) trash monsters are about right, but the bosses are extremely challenging.
There is at least 1 boss fight that cannot be won without grinding due to its being a dps race.  It is not obvious that grinding is the intended (and only) way to win the encounter.  Grinding 5 levels for that fight also reduced the boss's attacks from 40 dmg/hit to 9 dmg/hit.  I do not know how hard those bosses are supposed to hit, and I suspect the developers don't either.
Without grinding, nightmare bosses can take 1-10 hours to beat, including the time to learn their moves.

Unskippable dialogs
are ubiquitous and boring.  Even if I were interested in reading the story of a hero who rescues princesses and saves the world, my replays through the game would not be.
The intro cinematic is well done, but it can't be skipped either.  It takes at least 15 minutes to start a new game due to the unskippable cut scenes and dialog.

The controls
desperately need an autofire button and a way to hold down the magic charge button.  Using outside configuration utilities creates some problems in the game such as menus opening and closing due to autofire.  Holding down the magic charge button while imtermittently holding down the attack button and periodically jumping has led to some hand soreness.  Without autofire, the repetitive button presses will cause a lot of repetitive stress.
Even after some configuration, there are still occaisional phantom axis motions, and recharging magic immediately after casting makes it cast twice.

reviewText:
I am really amused how much good reviews this game got on steam. Most likely game is overrated because of nostalgia.

pros:
- Great platformer
- Story
- Soundtrack (for those who like such music)

cons:
- not an RPG at all (by modern standarts)
- unskippable video: long and predictable hence boring
- uninspired level design, too repetitive
- Spam attack button to win on hard difficulty.
- Spam attack button to win on nightmare difficulty.
*** for those who are going to argue about difficulty, yes, bosses may be tough, everything else - just spam attack button.

gameply:
1. Watch unskippable anime (or just minimize the game and do something fun)
2. Spam action button to skip tons of text (or read it if you haven't played any RPG video games in your life)
3. move your character for a few seconds
4. spam action button to skip text (or read it)
5. spam action button to defeat your enemies
6. spam action button to skip text
7. move your character and spam attack (which is the same as action") button
8. repeat

conclusion:
It is very easy to like this game:

Solution #1
you need a few things:
- love anime in general
- remember original game
- have nostalgia

Solution #2
You haven't played any RPG games before
date:
or played only jRPG games.

Solution #3
You just like easy-going pace of this ... well ... combination of non-interactive story and attack button simulator."

reviewText:
This game did not play as well as the trailer or screenshots portrayed (for me). I know this review is gonna get slated with negative feedback because I'm giving it a thumbs down, but if you're new to Ys then maybe give this a read. I'm not saying it's a bad game. I'm saying that as a Ys noob I just couldn't get into it.

The controls and combat system work kinda well, and you can remap the controller (which you'll need to do). The graphics and menu system are a little dated and detracted from the overall feel of the game, character design is meh, and you can't skip the lengthy video sequences. I found the music became rather unpleasant after an hour of playing.

The real killer for me though was the frustrating respawning of enemies every time I left and re-entered a room - even after I'd wiped everything out. This means you have to constantly battle the same dudes in the same places as you venture around solving the puzzles. I did not play enough to comment on the puzzles - I just don't have the inclination to fight the same enemies in a repetitive loop.

I understand this game may be a classic. I can only assume the abundance of rave reviews on Steam are from nostalgic Ys fans (which I can totally understand). For someone new to the Ys series (like me) I'm not sure this will go down as good as the screenshots look. For Ys fans of yesteryear, ofcourse you're gonna love this! I just couldn't get into it though :(

reviewText:
If you're a fan of tough as nails Action-RPG games, with boss fight that demands really on-point reflexes and quick thinking, then this game is for you. The game takes place inside one big tower that you climb, finding items and secrets along the way, and uncovering the reason behind the disappearance of the two Goddess.

With 3 Different playthrought, each of them having very different playstyle and a few different bosses, you can get alot of hours of fun. When you finish the story, you can also explore the optional modes : Boss Rush and Arena mode, in which you can test your skills fighting waves of ennemies or bosses.

I'd recommend playing on nightmare to experience the full intensity of the boss fights, which really, is what makes the Ys serie so good.

If you are already a Falcom fan, then I don't need to encourage you more to go play it.\nYs Origin brings you the tale of 700 years before the first game. The epic conflict you had in the first game is finally revealed, and what a Hell of a start it is. In terms of story it stands strong, and playing between each character may cause the game to feel repeatable, but it's actually done well. The gameplay may feel a bit stiff or slippery from time to time, but that's because Ys wasn't made to be this combo-ish action game; Adol isn't in it though, so I think that's where the problem lies. It's easy to get to the 100% clearing, but for 100% upgrades you really need to have a love for grinding. And as always in true Ys fashion, if you think this game isn't hard enough there is the Hellish Nightmare" mode.\nIt offers enough variety for you to play on and a loveable story. Though it may look weird from a linair look
recommended: the gap of 700 years should indicate that this one will stand on its own like it should be."

This game is loads of fun. Combat is smooth and rewarding, not too complicated but it's not just buttonmashing either. The platforming is done very well, challenging but not frustrating. Bosses are awesome (as far as I've gotten).
Only niggle (ugh, really steam? I'm saying n.i.g.g.l.e) is if you're really having trouble with a boss, it may be you're just underleveled. The game doesn't really emphasize your level so it's easy to miss, but I found that after going back and gaining 4 levels, the boss that was seriously kicking my behind, was suddenly pretty easy (although you'll still need to learn each boss' attackpatterns). Luckily though, grinding those 4 levels was very quick, probably no more than half an hour or so, and didn't feel like traditional grinding (aka boring) at all.
One comment though, everyone's saying how tough the game is... Well, it's not easy, but you might think it's a frustrating experience. As far as I'm concerned it's not. It offers a challenge, but it never feels unfair and to me personally on normal mode I find it's just right (and I'm not normally a glutton for punishment, still havent dared to start up dark soulds ;-))

DOUBLE REWRITE

Metroidvania-style platforming with a deeply-involving story? YES.

It takes a lot of patience to understand the entire detail of the first story between the first two characters (Yunica and Hugo) in their own perspectives, but understanding it is as rewarding as beating it at higher difficulties -- well worth the effort. But once you complete the game with both of those, you get a new character -- Toal -- and the real story begins. It's difficult to understand like before, but once you figure it out, it's excellent.

Yunica is a melee character; Hugo is a ranged character. Toal is a melee character, but his Boost mode turns him into a demon -- crucial for certain areas of the game. Some monsters take more damage to specific elements -- remember this.

And don't forget to buckle up.

reviewText: Ys Origins is a hack and slash platformer action RPG. You run around as one of 3 (only 2 are available before beating the game) classes and kill demons and level up increasing your damage, damage reduction, and hp. The gameplay itself is simple and fun. It has a pretty good story, an amazing soundtrack, and a ton of replayability. It's replayability factors come in an altered story for each character, boss rush modes, arena modes, achievments, and unlockables. Overall a really good game.

If you are a fan of action RPG's then this is the game for you. I'm about 7 hours into the game and yet to finish the game. The Normal difficulty is by no means a walk in the park. It has its tough moments but makes you feel like you did a major accomplishment once you get things figured out. Highly recommended game series.

You think this game is like a normal hack and slash game where you're just attacking every enemies like crazy? Well, you're right and wrong.
While it's true to normal mobs, the boss fight itself especially in nightmare difficulty is one hell of a fight.
You're required to fail and die a dozen times while learning the boss attack pattern, thinking about different approach and strategy before finally beat the crap out of it.

Sadly, the calculation of stats in this game is not RPG-like.
Gaining just one level can make a big difference in boss fight, especially in early game.
This game is a must for old school action jrpg fans.

I didn't know what to expect when I bought this game, but I've enjoyed it immensely.  The gameplay is somewhat reminiscent of the older Zelda games, and it's very, very fast-paced.  The graphics are definitely showing their age (the game was originally published in Japan in 2006 or so), but don't really detract from an otherwise enjoyable experience.

This has been one of my favorite recent purchases.  I hope XSEED is able to publish English translations of more stuff like this and Oath in Felghana (which is also fun, but not quite as good).

Pros:
-Fast paced, fun gameplay
-Interesting bosses
-Can reduce the difficulty of boss encounters by grinding a bit to raise character level (good if you're as bad at the boss fights as I am)
-Although grinding is necessary, there's an XP multiplier based on the number of hits you've made in the last few seconds, so it's possible to grind more quickly by fighting only in crowded rooms
-Responsive controls
-Good soundtrack
-Pretty good replay value--although the levels are all the same, each of the three playable characters has their own story arc with slight variations in the boss sequence and various other details
-Very good localization work by XSEED; doesn't feel rushed at all
-Runs very smoothly on modern hardware


Cons:
-Graphics a bit stale
-Long cutscenes and dialog that cannot be skipped (note: there IS an option in the settings applet which suppresses ALL video playback; good for skipping the intro on a second play-through)
-Character level scaling is very drastic:  Gaining two levels is usually sufficient to turn an unwinnable encounter into a cakewalk, so this tends to inspire a decent amount of grinding
-You NEED to find all items, particularly weapon power-ups; there are some enemies that are virtually impervious to damage if your weapon is at too low a level.

Previously cleared this prequel of YS  when the original Japanese version was released for PC, but purchased and cleared again for nostalgia when it was re-released on Steam.

Gameplay (as stated in another review of YS) is action-RPG'ish (resembling both Zelda and Diablo), as the player controls the main character from an overhead third person view. Characters can be unlocked within the game, offering up to 4 (one is unofficially unlocked) different selections each with their own types of skill sets. Characters can level up and acquire a set of sword-skills and magic to demolish enemies that are encountered throughout the game. Storyline is paced well, but can be tedious to understand, as the lore of YS is quite deep in this version of the game. Must play as all three storyline characters to completely understand each of their motives.

Music is also amazing, setting the tone of each and every stage the character enters. Graphics are outdated by modern standards, but the gameplay and music completely allow the user to forget about it.

Played through the entire game with all three characters (Yunica/Hugo/Toal).

Highly recommend. 5 out of 5 stars.

Get ready for long and difficult battles against the huge bosses of this game. You fight them regularly and thats the most spicing part of the game. You have to try again and again, but somehow it is very motivating, and you are blessed with satisfaction when you are done with it.\nThis game has all the requirements to be a good game, in the traditional way : a visual identity of its own, a good soundtrack (appropriate and just plain good to me), simple yet nicely used gameplay mechanics, which come to offer a great challenge, neither too easy nor annoyingly hard.\n9/10
good game worth the playthroughs i would say.
Amazing game, simple, fun and challenging, i need to play MORE!

Absolutely amazing game. Top tier gameplay, great storyline, and unbelievable replayability. If you're playing on Hard or Nightmare, the game provides a good challenge, but is never frustrating; Normal is a bit too easy for my liking, but is still a completely viable way to enjoy the game. If you enjoy games like Castlevania or Devil May Cry, you should definitely pick this up.
fun, fast-paced, and tough action RPG. Action gameplay aspect is much better than Diablo, I guess.

If you love the likes of Ys Seven, Ys: Oath in Felghana, and anything in the Ys Universe for that matter.  This is a must play.  Ys Origin continues to impress and dazzle with wonderful 2D Sprites and 3D Environments, as well as spectacular boss fights.   Must Play!
Not a review, but simply a recommendation.

I rarely finish games, but I finished Ys Origin twice and almost went for a third do-over.

The game as its core is quite fun. Mash Z at baddies. Baddies come straight at you, pushing you towards progress. Build that experience multiplier with every hit. Room emptied? Quick, rush to the next one, don't let it fade away! Mash, mash, hack and slash! Faster, Yunica, faster!

The part where the game forces you to essentially stop having fun mashing enemies to pieces are decidedly the least fun, and the very first chapter is probably the worst in this regard.

For the rest, however, the game doesn't look upon you for pushing recklessly forward: the game recognizes that there is nothing wrong with W+M1 (or, rather, Z+↑); it embraces the euphoria you get by building up your attack chain and going from monster to monster, building up buffs in the progress, leveling up without a break -- there is none of that YOU JUST GOT ONE SKILL POINT STOP EVERYTHING YOU ARE DOING AND SPEND IT RIGHT THE HELL NOW" stuff
date: and the upgrades you CAN buy can wait in between flurries. Hell: the way NPCs in the game described Yunica in their fixed scripts matched perfectly the way I was playing -- accidental Z-mashing-based rolepaying has no right feeling this rewarding.\n\nYou spend 10 hours finishing the game
recommended: and you feel rewarded and spent and awesome. And then the game says you've unlocked a new character.\n\nThis is where I usually tune out; I don't really tend to do NG+s with rare exceptions. Ys Origin however was just so much fun it earned a chance for one

even though I've actually been playing on easy throughout -- it's still a game from Japan and I do NOT trust their sense of scale when it comes to difficulty.

This japanese arpg game is a blast. Awesome storyline, enchanting world, fun bossfights.
The enemies in every level are usually pretty easy, but the bossfights are a nice challenge. Most bosses took me a couple hours of retries on the hardest difficulty (playing as Yunica on nightmare, Hugo is much easier). The combat is smooth, fast paced, and pretty simple actually, but it's the bossfights where you have to get a bit creative.

Oh and the soundtrack on this one is pure gold.

8.5/10

It's the game Falcom made after Oath in Felghana. The combat system is even more polished, the boss battles even more crazy, the music even more fantastic (in places), and the player characters even more talkactive. While it lacks an overworld it doesn't skimp on providing an interesting and varied labyrinth to go through.\nIf you haven't bought Oath in Felghana yet, you should. If you haven't, you'll find what I wrote above (in parts) easy to believe! Origin improves on the amazing gameplay of its predecessor, while adding more to be awed at! And it's a real PC exclusive game!\nAs before, though, might be too hardcore for some. Graphics were good for their time, but aren't spectacular now. You don't need to care about the story.
If you enjoy RPG's This is a MUST PLAY!

An all-around great RPG. Extremely well-designed in every category. Feels like playing one of those old-school, memorable, classic games. Three characters (one unlockable) with different fighting styles and their own take on the same story. Much easier than the previous games in the series (it's a good thing.) I really enjoyed this game and have no complaints with it.

This game is an isometric Devil May Cry.  It is absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing crazy.  The Sprites on Polygons artstyle is the only complaint I have, other than a more or less standard story.  Even then, the story's shaping up to be better than a lot of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t in other games, and the art is pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed well done.  It is delightfully paced, it is action ♥♥♥♥ing packed and it will make sweet, sweet love to your ♥♥♥ with its excellent soundtrack, intense bosses and crazy ♥♥♥♥ it allows you to do.

Live the legend that is Ys in Ys: Origin. Search through a sprawling and multi tiered tower that you may remember from other Ys games for the first time on a quest to find the twin goddesses and thwart demons and outsiders alike. While easier and much more linear than others in the series, this game provides multiple characters with different playstyles and controls the same as modern Ys installments for fast and decisive action. A gloriously atmospheric and rocking soundtrack supports the different zones of the tower while monsterous and menacing bosses bar your path to your ultimate goal of rescuing the goddesses.

The various ways to complete this game depending on what character you pick through their combat style makes this game very replayable if you are a fan of Ys or real-time action RPGs. Through the use of magic artifacts and different weapons you are able to find unique weaknesses in enemies and exploit them viciously. While your equipment is very limited for a Ys game, the items you can pick up are mostly the ones you know and love from other installments as they are recovered from the broken land of Ys here initially.

I never had a Ys game before Oath, but with this, I and II (remade with the old bump" combat style)
date: and Oath as well in my library I always keep coming back to Ys for another adventure."

8.5/10

Ys Origins is a hack and slash platformer action RPG. You run around as one of 3 (only 2 are available before beating the game) classes and kill demons and level up increasing your damage, damage reduction, and hp. The gameplay itself is simple and fun. It has a pretty good story, an amazing soundtrack, and a ton of replayability. It's replayability factors come in an altered story for each character, boss rush modes, arena modes, achievments, and unlockables. Overall a really good game.

If you are a fan of action RPG's then this is the game for you. I'm about 7 hours into the game and yet to finish the game. The Normal difficulty is by no means a walk in the park. It has its tough moments but makes you feel like you did a major accomplishment once you get things figured out. Highly recommended game series.

You think this game is like a normal hack and slash game where you're just attacking every enemies like crazy? Well, you're right and wrong.
While it's true to normal mobs, the boss fight itself especially in nightmare difficulty is one hell of a fight.
You're required to fail and die a dozen times while learning the boss attack pattern, thinking about different approach and strategy before finally beat the crap out of it.

Sadly, the calculation of stats in this game is not RPG-like.
Gaining just one level can make a big difference in boss fight, especially in early game.

Pros: Really great selection of tools with uses in combat and in puzzles, varied and interesting enemy designs, superb boss fights, very energetic soundtrack.

Cons: Poor feedback when hit (there's no sound effect, just a red number that pops up that I missed a few times,) Bosses have VERY deep health pools when compared to how easily some enemies will fall so a certain degree of grinding may be necessary, and you can't pause the game when fighting a boss (I think this is to prevent players from teleporting out of the room to avoid a loss or something, but I should still be able to pause the game.)

Even with those issues I still had a great time. Strongly recommended.

The only reason I haven't played more of this game (and if you look I've played quite a few hours already) is that the relentless hammering of the buttons on my gamepad is giving my wrist problems. It's one of those few games that's just a pure joy to play, with constant action, well designed levels and awesome bosses, as well as great, classic style artwork. Easy to pick up, not too complicated, but still offering 40+ hours of gameplay. Definitely worth it, even not on sale. My only gripe is that you never leave the tower, and I'd like to explore the world of Ys a bit more. I guess I'll have to pick up the other games!
This game is a must for old school action jrpg fans.
This is a great old school style game!

I think they made this game entirely so they could remake the Ys I & II bosses with the superlative Ys VI engine. Not that I mind! Though I don't know why they chose to make a game based on the worst thing about Ys I (stuck in the tower for half the game, now you're stuck in the tower for the whole game!) But it's good because the Ys VI mechanics are a work of action game art.
Hack and slash console game.  What is there not to like?  If you liked any of the previous Ys series, this will hit those same buttons for you.

Amazing soundtrack, very good plataform game with unique battle system, game reminds Legend of Zelda in terms of powerups. Very action oriented game and Bosses that will make you think a little instead of hack'n'slashing him non stop.
Did I mentioned that the game have a amazing soundtrack? The game have a amazing soundtrack.
Game is the beginning of the series hence the name Origin, so if you plan in get into the series here is a good start.
<3~

Wish Adol was a girl instead?  Covered.
Want to be a mage instead of a melee master?  Covered.
Want to play one of the bad guys?  Covered.
Another episode in the series that does not disappoint.

I never realised how much fun this game could be! It combines RPG with platforming and hack and slash style gameplay to form this truly amazing yet simple game to life!\n\nIntruder gives his trespassing seal of approval!
A truly amazing series. Easily one of the best I've ever played.

If you still have a wet nurse, this game is not for you. If you still need a baby sitter when your parent(s) aren't home, this game is not for you. If you like games like (Insert pretty much any recent AAA title here) and the hand holding that goes with it, this game is not for you.\n\n...But... If you love a challenge, if you love frantic, yet still skill based gameplay that rewards talent, and punishes mashing, and if you love bosses that EARN the right to be referred to as a boss, then YOU. WILL. LOVE. THIS. GAME.

I really like the old school feel of this title.  the controls are simple and there isn't alot of menu or inventory management, just some good old real time RPG monster bashing.  plenty of bonuses for speed too.

This is a fun old school style RPG game with a very Japanese feel. The story is kind of typical for this type of game and there is a lot of dialogue as usual, but the graphics are very nice, if simple, and the controls are good. Bosses aren't easy and the fighting can get monotonous after awhile, but I enjoyed this game nonetheless. Don't know if it's worth $20 but I recommend picking it up is it's on sale.

A solid hacky-slashy JRPG, Origin is the release followup to Oath & storyline prequel to Ys I & II (which are on steam,btw). The three main characters in the game play quite differently from each other, Yunica feeling pretty close to Adol's style in Oath, while Hugo is more shmup-ey. The gameplay is pretty much as fast as Oath was, although a bit easier if compared to it,which is a good thing if you thought Oath was hard...

Graphically. it's once again the same deal as Oath. The game is old so it runs on toasters, but it looks great if you can bump up stuff like AA and AF to the max and maintain 60FPS, making the whole package feel fluid.

To sum: If you like hack-slash JRPG's, it's a pretty great game to play.

I never in my wildest dreams imagined I would spend almost 100 hours playing this game and still not get bored with it. The action is beyond top-notch and should be challenge enough for even the most skilled players. There is nothing that compares to the feeling of satisfaction one gets from beating an Ys boss on the nightmare difficulty setting. I highly recommend this to anyone who likes role playing games, isometric action games or people who just want to see more niche Japanese PC titles on Steam.

This a fast-paced, exciting RPG with an addictive soundtrack and tons of action. It's like The Legend of Zelda on steroids. Including the almost endless dialogues. The generic art direction, story and elements typical in J-RPG are balanced with a frenzy of hack, slash and spell casting.\n\nThree story modes out of each playable character, really Hugo, the mage, is the easiest way of beating the game.
Epic game. Must buy!!

A prequel to the long-running Ys series, Ys Origins tells the story of Darm Tower before the events of Ys I & II. Unlike most Ys games, you don't play as familiar, red-haired protagonist Adol Christin, but rather one of two characters (there is also a 'secret' third character), the axe-wielding Yunica and the mage Hugo. This is a different take on the series than most entries, and is a welcome change as there is a lot of variety with the playstyles of each character, and this also adds to the replay value as you can play through the game multiple times with different characters, the story being slightly different for each as well.

The story is rather bare-bones, but mildly interesting, particularly if you are an Ys fan or a fan of traditional fantasy storylines. Nothing to set the world on fire, but the main characters are likable (particularly Yunica) and the story does not get in the way of the game's main strength: the fast-paced, action-RPG combat. If you've never played an Ys game, particularly the older titles, the game plays as a mix of a top-down hack n' slash and a 2.5 platformer. Many of the skills you gain have dual uses for both platforming and combat, and there is a decent variety of abilities. That being said, there is much more combat than platforming in the game, and while the platforming can be occasionally frustrating, the combat is where the series, and this game in particular, truly shines. Combat requires you to quickly chain together attacks, make smart use of your skills, and avoid enemy attacks by dodging and jumping. Basic enemies are not too difficult, though there is a wide variety of enemy types to fight, all with their different skillsets and strategies. The bosses are the main attraction, being both difficult and surprisingly epic for a game without state-of-the-art graphics.

One more thing about this game, and the Ys series as a whole: the music is FANTASTIC! Some of the best videogame music I have ever heard is from this series, and this entry keeps the bar set high. There are quite a few stellar tracks, many of which are boss themes. Overall, I would reccomend this game to any fan of the series, any fan of action RPG's, and any fan of Japanese games. If none of these categories apply to you, then pick this gem up on sale. Trust me, you will not be dissapointed, and maybe you'll become another fan of this underappreciated (but spectacular) series.

Pick this for your intro to YS series as Origin was the first story wise and the latest PC release of this franchise.
