In my opinion, this is the best Ys title currently available on Steam/PC.

If you've played other Ys games, you know what to expect. Compared to the other titles, Origin is reasonably short (roughly 6 hours) but has 3 playable characters. Playing the game with all three characters does add a significant amount of replay value, as they play completely differently, and also have some unique story elements. Once you're done with the three main campaigns, there's also an arena mode for an extra challenge.

As usual, the soundtrack is fantastic, and the controls are spot on.

This is an old school classic that should not be missed. If you grew up on games like grandia, star ocean, secret of mana, and the like then this will be right up your ally. This game is worth buying; just wait for it to go on sale for about $6. 9/10

Ys series in general are not very long and their challenge level is fair with minimal grinding required. This one is a bit of exception in length and challenge, but not as negative aspects. While the length for one character is the average of any other Ys, the replay value lies in the fact there are THREE characters in total, each one with their own play style and emphasizing one aspect or another. And the story also changes itself, showing things that happens with that character while it was not on camera to another, or sometimes fate itself will twist and a whole new situation will unfold.\n\nFor those seeking for challenge, bosses and enemies can be blazed through in easier difficulties, grinded in average ones, or skillfully fought in later difficulties. I could go on and on in an in-depth analysis of this game, but I will keep it short and simple: if you want a good story and challenge, Ys Origin is your game.

Excellent game, hardly any problems to speak of. Would recommend to basically anyone who can still appreciate older style games and who isn't turned off by cheesy japanese storytelling. This game is also very friendly to the PC master race, supporting resolutions beyond 1080p and refresh rates beyond 60Hz. The game actually renders very well at higher resolutions, though the textures don't look super great.

Ys Origin is essentially a 3D action platformer in the style of Alundra for PS1, and to some extent the 2D Zelda games. Emphasis is primarily on combat, but also on finding your way through the game. Each area has a few branching sub-areas which you must navigate to find a key to the boss room. This usually involves going through the area until you reack a fork in the road where reaching the end of one fork will activate some switch that will allow you to grab the boss key from the other side of the fork.

Combat is very fast consists of attacking, using special abilities, jumping, and some other moves. You have 3 special abilities that you can use in combat that offer you some mix of damage, utility, and range. The abilities are different for each character but serve the same general purpose. Part of the game is figuring out which ability is most effective for the area you are exploring.

The best part about this game is without a doubt the bosses. Every fight throws something completely unexpected, yet refreshingly original at you. Very rarely will you ever go up to a boss and whack it until it dies. Almost every boss has a weakness that must be revealed in some way before you get the chance to actually deal damage. And each boss has attacks that you need to dodge in creative ways instead of just running in a circle.

I will give the example of what was probably my favorite boss in the game. The boss is basically a centipede where each pair of legs was its own section of body. The way to kill the boss is to destroy each body segment. The problem is that each time you destroy a body segment, it will start spewing poison bombs that explode if left on the ground too long. This severely inhibits your mobility and also throws a lot of extra damage into the mix. Keep in mind the boss is constantly moving, so you not only need to dodge everything, but also catch up to it so you can actualyl deal damage. By the end of the fight the field is entirely covered in poison bombs and you have to find a way to weave through them, jump on the boss, and kill the last segment before you die. This boss killed me probably 20 times, but it was still a great experience because each time you would make tiny optimizations or notice something new about an attack that would let you avoid it more easily.

Though this game actually involves very little actual platforming, the game utilizes 3D space very well. You are constantly moving up and down through the environment which is a nice change from the typical top-down games where everything is just a flat plane. 3D space is even utilized in combat, with airborne enemies that must be taken down with jumping attacks, to boss attacks that can only be dodged by jumping. From my boss example above, the same boss is able to climb on walls, going completely out of your reach. While doing this he will shoot lightning at you, which you must avoid to keep from falling behind. However, you have a special ability that when charged up has a huge vertical range. If you want, you can hit the boss with this move while he is on the wall. This introduces a risk into the fight by letting you hit the boss while he is high up, but you need to come to a stop to use the attack, opening up the possibility of getting hit by the lightning. Many combat moments in the game involes this same sort of risk/reward that weighs more damage against a higher probability of getting hit, which leads me into my next point...

This game has no consumable healing items and no way to heal yourself during combat. This is especially relevant during boss fights. You only have one health bar, and you have to kill the boss before he kills you. This makes for very tense fights, knowing that each mistake is permanent, each risk you take is a real risk and can't be immediately undone by healing yourself. These fights are reminiscent of many boss fights in JRPGs where you desperately hope that you can kill the boss before your healers run out of MP. You can't cheese out any boss by spamming healing items each time you take a lot of damage. This game forces you to learn the patterns and exploit the weaknesses of every single boss. The same is true during regular combat, but normal enemies drop health pickups and there is also an accessory in the game that allows you to heal which standing still. Even so, the game sometimes throws extra tough enemies your way, and you are forced to kill the lot of them in one go which can be just as challenging, especially if none of them drop a health pickup.


Now for some minor complaints:

The game starts throwing really annoying enemies at you late in the game. While I appreciate challening combat where you don't just mash a button until everything dies, these enemies also flat out waste your time either by being extremely resistant to damage or having small, spread out periods of vulnerability.

The plot of the game is pretty bottom of the barrel. It's the exact same good vs evil, friendship is power, find your true strength generic japanese crap that we've all heard a million times before. The game isn't quite as cheery as something like Dragon Quest, but you can pretty much predict the exact plot of the game if you've played any other game that follows the same story structure.


Here is some stuff that may be good or bad, depending on your tastes:

While there are no healing items in the game, you can always just grind levels and become near-invulnerable if you are having trouble with a boss. I would really recomend not doing this, as every boss in the game is beatable in a reasonable amount of tries without this, but it's still possible. Sometimes grinding a bit can really help out, as being underleveled during a boss fight is extremely punishing as you can sometimes be dealing damage in the single digits and taking huge chunks of damage for small mistakes.

The game takes place in a tower and only in a tower. This means no towns, you never encounter any new NPCs to talk to, the only shop" is at save points
date: and the only way to go is up. This does bring about a few perks as well though. If you like streamlined games with no fluff
recommended:
this is perfect for you. The tower structure also lends itself to being a game with almost zero backtracking through previous levels. The only times you do this are for quick story progression segments.


Overall
hoursPlayed: this game is great and worth playing at least once
voteText: if not multiple times with each playable character. It is very reminiscent of older games that were made by a small team of dedicated devs
helpfulPercent: and you can tell the game was made with love. If you are already a Ys fan
votesHelpful: expect something above and beyond. If not
votesTotal: maybe save this one for last becuase I truly think it is the cream of the crop as far as the PC titles go."

reviewText:
Note 1: This is currently being played on Nightmare difficulty. That being said, your mileage may vary on how these games compare (how easy is is to make money, gain exp, etc.)

Note 2: I will be comparing this to Oath in Felghana's gameplay. Spoilers for both games will be unmarked, so please read at your discretion.
This is a review of the game from a technical/gameplay standpoint  not  a review regarding the storyline, graphics, etc. I am writing this review for those that wish to play the Ys games in chronological order.

For those of you that don't know, Origin, Oath in Felghana, and Ark of Napishtim use the same engine. However, OiF and Origin were released after Ark of Napishtim, in that order, and thus were tweaked" or "improved
date:
rather, in terms of combat, stat growth, and money gain. Playing in chronological order means playing Origin, then Oif, then Ark, and getting used to things that might be missing, as you go through the series.

Now, I've played Origin all the way through on all characters on Nightmare difficulty, and the first thing to compare between Origin and Oif, is that Yunica and Adol play similarly to each other, without being exactly the same. For example, while Yunica and Adol's fire spells function identically, Yunica gets her fire magic from a sword, which does slightly more damage than her normal weapon, but swings slower. Other than that, their attack patterns are pretty similar, with Adol doing more thrusting as opposed to Yunica swinging her axe about (which makes sense, considering you don't stab with it).

In Origin, your dash attack has a chance of lowering the enemy's defence, including bosses. This is incredibly helpful as it can be chained into your normal combo. In OiF, you still have a dash attack, however, instead of lowering the enemy's defence, it is a quick 3-hits, that can be chained into your normal combo. That being said, in Origin, it's imperative to learn how to effectively use your dash attack, where as in OiF, you can almost completely disregard it, and get by just fine.

The second thing to note, OiF and Origin have a thing called Boost, which functions similar to a Limit Break, if you will; while it's active, movement and attack speed is increased, while damage is greatly reduced. However, Origin added an additional power to that, called Burst, a special attack that, when activated, will use the remaining time on your Boost. The attack varies for each character, but is nice to have, as it's essentially a panic button, to go along with your Limit Break. You don't  need  it, but it's nice to have, in the situations where you are surrounded by enemies with 3 HP, and no way out.

Regarding the difficulty as a whole, of both games, Nightmare is incredibly hard, even frustrating at times, in both Origin and OiF. The difference, however, is that OiF has boss fights that are much more demanding in terms of snap decisions, timing, and reflexes, whereas the dungeons leading up to said fights, are a fun challange. Not particularly terrifying or anything. The first boss, Ellefale, is both a perfect representation of what to expect later on, as well as being a nice throwback to Ys 2, where everything died by fire. If you try to dodge her attacks too early, they will chace after you, and you'll get hit, and likewise, dodge too late, and you get hit. For a first boss, having to learn the timing right then and there is incredibly demanding, especially when you die in 2 or 3 hits. Boss fights like Gyalva and Gildias very much felt the same way, requiring precise timing, quick thinking, and not using every tool in your arsenal will cost you your life.

On the other hand, Origin had much harder dungeons, yet had less demanding boss fights (not to say that they aren't exactly harder"). I found myself dying quite a bit

reviewText:
This game is outstanding. I wasn't sold on the demo, but I got this one on sale. So happy I decided to do that. The demo does not do it justice, not by any means.

Pros

- The gameplay is the best part of this game. Fast paced and challenging in a good way. You're not going to find yourself losing because of cheap tricks, it's almost always something you didn't do correctly. The boss fights are intense and unforgiving. You have to learn how to beat a boss, you won't be able to mash buttons and luck your way through it. They demand skill, and will likely take multiple tries on a reasonable difficulty level before you figure out how to counter everything a boss can throw at you.
-The stories are also an amazing aspect of the game. Each character is unique and will draw you into their individual approaches toward the main plot.
- The graphics are simple and beautiful, and perfect for this type of game. I love that they didn't try to make this into a movie, like the idea seems to be for far too many games today. If you want a game that's going to blow you away with the gameplay and not make you feel like you're spending 5 minutes playing and then 15 minutes watching a pretty animated movie, this is the game for you.

Cons

- The only con I have, and it may just be my situation, is that my mouse does not like this game at all. It seems to lag horribly, and this makes particular parts of the game a real mess. It can be very frustrating when you lose a battle not because you did anything wrong, but because you were trying to move one direction, but because of latency issues, you move another. Also, I've found that the skills (controlled by my mouse wheel) seem to switch even when I'm sure I haven't touched the mouse wheel at all. The game can be played with a keyboard, but that presents it's own challenges. This game really seems like it's perfectly suited for a controller.

Overall I wouldn't hesitate to buy this one. The difficulty levels are scaled perfectly, and there's one for every type of gamer. It's one that you'll probably keep playing just to complete everything about it that you possibly can, because it's that addicting.
Excellent game!
Best Ys game I have played so far. I like it better than Oath I am playing now.
No walls crushed.

The more I immerse myself in the Ys series, the more enamored I become.  This is one solid little franchise.  There are so many things that Falcom does right in caring for this classic property, and I have high hopes for future Ys games I will be playing.

This is yet another perfect little charming gem of an action RPG.  It mixes 2D sprite animation and seamless 3D architecture to create a style both retro and timeless.  The care and attention payed to the characters, story, music, and ys heritage is truly admirable.

Design wise, this game is a typical dungeon crawl, but the challenge is quite thrilling during boss fights.  The exploration aspect can get a bit tedious if you play through the game multiple times in quick succession, but I imagine this can be offset by tweaking difficulty levels to your liking.

On that note, the story of Ys Origin plays out with a Roshamon style redundancy; with three individual character's story-lines.  Much of the joy of this game comes from experiencing the events of the narrative from these different perspectives.  Granted, there are slight differences in each Character's narrative, with only one (Claw's) considered 'cannon', but walking through the game in each of their shoes lets you become much more familiar with the characters and the world in which they live.  I can't imagine having only played through this game with a single character, and I found each separate run interesting and challenging due to the different play mechanics.

It's a faithful loveletter to the Lore Falcom has developed for Ys over the last several decades.  The characters, the settings, and even the music is heavily inspired by past games in the franchise.  Now at the time of this writing, I had managed to play the steam releases of Ys 1&2, as well as Oath in Felghana (remake of ys 3).  These games stand perfectly fine on their own story wise, and it is absolutely unnecessary for anyone to have any prior knowledge of the franchise to get your money's worth.  That being said, each entry also helps to paint a beautifully detailed picture of a larger whole.  Falcom seem quite devoted to the world they've created, and the relationship between games is actually quite nuanced.

I'm so very glad I played through this, and I encourage everyone to take it for a spin.  If you're only interested in a charming hack 'n slash romp, by all means coast through it.  If you're at all interested in the story of Ys, I very much encourage you to experience each story line.  On the lower difficulties, each play through should take about 8 hours.  I, myself, played the first round on normal, then coasted through the next two on easier settings for a total playtime of 26 hours.

Such an Fun and Simple made game with difficult bossfights and easy to follow storyline.\nJust played through this game and I will say that this was not the last time I will put my fingers\non this great little gem.
Massively addicting game, definitely a game worth checking out if you're into fast paced hack and slash games.
It's Ys. this alone warrants at least 5 playthroughs

It feels like one of those old SNES Games, but with a lot of more detail and mobility. perfect for when you want something different that what standard games are now\n\nThe story is kinda standard at first, does not make fall for the characters, because it feels like your classical problem at first, but in the end mixed up with the gameplay, i can say for sure is worth every penny

Ys Origin is a good game. It's worth every bit of money I spent on it. But it's not perfect. There are some flaws with the game that prevents the game from being great.

1) The story
-If you've already played Ys back in the golden age of the Super Famicom, you'll probably appreciate the story in this prequel. But if you never played them, chances are you'll be disappointed with the story. It's very cliche and predictable. Even worse is the story for each characters. Long story short, each of them aren't parallel with each other.

2) The difficulty
-Hard games are good and welcomed but the difficulty in Ys Origin is borderline cheap and unfair. Basically, the higher difficulty means enemies have more health, takes less damage and deals more damage to you. It pretty much boils down to grinding enough levels by killing the same enemies over and over again, just to inflict damage more than 1 to the enemy. That, and finding power-up item to strengthen your weapon because if not, the later stages becomes nearly impossible. Unless you're a masochist or have a lot of free time, just play it on normal or easy.

3) The gameplay
-It's fun enough for a few hours, especially after getting all abilities but it get pretty old as you play. Equipment, stats, abilities, items, etc are all streamlined and simplified. You'll be begging for more complexity the more you play. Almost no exploration or secret locations to discover, a few unneeded platforming and a non-existent puzzles to solve.

I'm giving this a thumbs up simply because it succeeded in giving me a brief moment of enjoyment.

RECOMMENDED        : For Ys fans. If not, buy this during a sale.
NOT RECOMMENDED: Player who seeks more complexity than slash-fest J Action RPG

Ys Origin do everything it promises perfectly, from gameplay to history, everything is done exceptionally. The characters are all well done and charismatic, the dialogue is great and playing with the 3 main characters and seeing how they are with each other is one of the best things about this game. The replay value is very high, the 3 playable characters are very different to play with (Yunica is a close ranged/mid speed type, Hugo is a long ranged/slow speed type and the secret character is a close ranged/fast speed type), I reccomend to finish it at least 2 times for the true ending. The game truly shines mechanics-wise in the boss fights, they're hard but not unfair and can be a lot easier if you grind. If you just want to fight some bosses, there's the boss rush mode after you finish the story. The soundtrack is also extremely good, with musics that suits all the moments in the game very well.\n\nIn short, Ys Origin is a masterpiece and a excellent prequel for a excellent series. Even if you don't like JRPGs, you should at least give this game a chance.

Fantastic game. I've only played Oath and Origins so far. This one is far and away my favorite of the two. It has everything you could ask for. Great replay value, great story, great character developments, music, and gameplay. There's not much missing here if you're looking for a super solid action rpg. Definitely recommend this game and even worth playing through with all three characters for the extra story. You won't regret it.
Really fun and engaging combat. Varied areas and rooms to fight in. Intersting bosses. Wish there was less backtracking.

Picked up some colorful a** f*** vocabulary because of this f***ing game.\n\nThis was my first introduction to the Ys series and I must say this was the first game in a long while that has challenged me in skill and not luck. By that I mean, this game actually takes skill to play as opposed to some difficult" games which don't rely on player skill as opposed to how lucky you get on attack patterns
recommended:
etc.

I played as Yunica on Nightmare mode on my first (and so far only) play through.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Likes:
-fluid feel of the game movement and attacks
-especially enjoyed the invulerability frame of the lightning spell and the fact that it took skill to use correctly (and i felt was almost absolutely required while playing nightmare mode)
-Most of all I enjoyed the difficulty and uniqueness of each and every boss you fought. Each boss had its own way to be defeated which wasn't simply "Smack till dieded"

Dislikes:
-Don't unlock a special character until you've beaten the game once...
-Need to play the game with said special character just to unlock secret ending & secret boss fight
-Too much running around on occassion
-Game requires a bit of grinding to be able to progress if you're playing higher difficulties
--------------------------------------------------------------------

All in all
hoursPlayed: 10/10. Highly recommend the game. I also highly recommend nightmare mode first try if you enjoy a challenge like me

reviewText: I played Ys 7 some time ago and i loved it. When this hit the sales i lost it and i had to buy it. The gameplay is so rare, the soundtrack is amazing (i'm a violinist so yeah i love it), the story is amazing just like Ys 7 the only problem would be the mouse controls but that is pretty much it. I give it a 10/10. Legendary game series.
Ys Origin is one of the greatest action RPGs ever made.  Unless you hate action RPGs with great combat, bosses, characters and interesting narrative you should play Ys Origin.
This game is everything I expected it to be.

This was my first YS game and I loved it. Story wise, you need to play the game at least twice to get the true plot of the game. Gameplay wise, its pretty simple and there isn't much of a difficulty curve. Boss fights can be challenging. Overall this game offers a ton of replay value and I completely recommend it for someone looking for a simple but fun action RPG.

The greatest game ever made in my opinion. It has nice graphics, an addictive story, awesome music, & easy controls.\nWhat more could you ask for. I have already beat all 3 story lines, but I still want to keep playing. If you are a fan of the Ys series this one is a must have.

Fantastic game with fast-paced action, and intense boss fights (depending on difficulty). The story is also pretty good, and unfolds differently depending on which character you play as, but there's only one true end. Definitely would recommend to anyone who likes a good rpg.

This is, so far, one of the most satisfying action games that I have played in recent years. It is deceptively simple in its mechanisms, but it adds layers of different components and tricks as time goes on.  The gameplay is intense, but strategic. The music is equally intense. The game rewards you the faster you cut down foes by rewarding additional XP per hit, but that counter will decrease as time goes on; this encourages you to keep progressing. The boss-fights are intriguing, and are (deservingly) much more difficult than the enemies around them. This requires a more tactical approach than just mashing buttons; you may end up dead before you can blink if you don't pace yourself.  The platforming elements require timing and focus.

Your mileage may vary on a few of these next details, but I think that they are good to note. The game doesn't force you through several of the immersion-breaking and random overworld fetch-quests that can detract from other JRPGs, but at the cost of no overword (that I have seen) to explore. I see it as a pro for this particular game as the world around the tower is a wasteland rather than a varied environment to explore. Due to the facts that the game only appears to take place in a tower, that it is an action game based on a relatively simple to use combat system, and that the game is fast-paced, I suspect that some playing this would tire quickly. Play on Nightmare difficulties for getting the most out of the game: truly exhilarating boss-fights.

All in all, an excellent game that I recommend highly.
Ys:origins just like all games in the Ys series is an excellent action game.\nThree playable characters,lots of secrets to explore and puzzles to solve,intense boss fights.\nA must play.
♥♥♥♥in awesome. The Ys games are some of best arpg's when it comes to gameplay and controls (not counting the first games). Responsive and quick. Not for the unskilled pleb.
love this game <3  boss fights hard as ♥♥♥♥, a really good challenge

One of the better Ys games in my opinion.

For those that don't know Ys (after the first game), it's an action RPG with 3D plateformer with a 3/4 top camera centered on the character.

In this game, you scale a tower with 2 different characters (and 1 to unlock).

While you can grind if you really want some specific things (like beating a boss that's supposed to act as a sort-of-unbeatable one), it's usually not necessary in normal difficulty.

Decent graphic style, good gameplay and nice soundtrack, if action rpg of old is your thing (think 2D zelda style combat), then you might really have a good time with this game.
